story:
• Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page
  • My grandad Frank William Bagley passed away in hospital 2018 when he lost his fight to Stage 4 Non Hodgkin Lymphoma cancer which spread throughout his body. After endless amounts of chemotherapy and Radiotherapy his body did not react the way we hoped. Frank was a family man and was as deep as the ocean. He loved his crosswords and cowboy films, he loved socialising in his local club in Southwick and had a lot of friends and family who loved him dearly . Originally was born in hendon and became a welder, lived in St Patricks Garth  until he married and had children. Theres so much I could tell you about my grandad but I know he hoped that no one would have to suffer like he did battling cancer 
  • I want to give something back to Macmillan as it is an amazing charity 
  • Here are a few facts and statistics; In the UK, more than 13,000 people are diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma each year. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma can occur at any age, but your chances of developing the condition increase as you get older, with just over a third of cases diagnosed in people over 75. Slightly more men than women are affected.

  • Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is a type of cancer that develops in the lymphatic system, a network of vessels and glands spread throughout your body. The lymphatic system is part of your immune system. Clear fluid called lymph flows through the lymphatic vessels and contains infection-fighting white blood cells known as lymphocytes. In non-Hodgkin lymphoma, the affected lymphocytes start to multiply in an abnormal way and begin to collect in certain parts of the lymphatic system, such as the lymph nodes (glands). The affected lymphocytes lose their infection-fighting properties, making you more vulnerable to infection. The most common symptom of non-Hodgkin lymphoma is a painless swelling in a lymph node, usually in the neck, armpit or groin.

story:
This fundraising page is in memory of our beautiful Anisha, or Ani as she was known to many.  She was taken from us far too early, after a very long and tough battle with cancer.

Anisha was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2016 and after months of chemotherapy, radiotherapy and a major operation, she was clear of cancer and ready to get her life back on track.

In 2017, she married Rakesh and started making plans for the future.  As she once said, "I finally got my happy ever after"

Unfortunately, after only a few months in early 2018, she was told that the cancer had returned and spread to other parts of her body.  Anisha knew this wouldn't be easy, however showed great strength and courage during her many rounds of treatment knowing she had alot to fight for, Aryan, Rakesh, Leah, Kian and her parents.  

Her treatment continued for a few years but because of her positive attitude and mental strength you would never have known.  Regardless of how she was feeling, she was always smiling. Sadly after many rounds of chemotherapy, she lost her fight on Tuesday 27th October 2020.

Anisha was the strongest, bravest and most courageous person one could ever hope to meet, so strong that we never believed she would lose this fight.

She was a loving Mom, Wife, Daughter, Sister and Friend and the sad reality is that cancer took her from us.

She is at peace now but she would have wanted us to try and help find a cure and save lives.

While flowers are appreciated, the family propose donations to Macmillan Cancer Charity who were a great support to Anisha.

Thank You.

Jai Shree Krishna 🙏🙏🙏

story:
Hey, thanks for checking out my page. So, it seems we will soon be going into another national lockdown, and with the thought of that looming I’ve decided to set myself a little challenge...

To have something positive to focus on and to improve my overall health and well-being, I’ve decided I’m going to go alcohol free for a whole year. Hopefully  raising some money for a good cause along the way too.

I’d say I’m an average drinker, who usually enjoys a glass of fizz, a nice glass of red wine or G&T, usually with a meal or socially with friends. Lots of celebrations are coming up in the next few months including Christmas and my birthday, so this really will be a test of my resolve.

The challenge kicks off on Wednesday 4th November 2020 and will finish on Thursday 4th November 2021.

I’m raising money for the British Heart Foundation who do incredible work and research into heart related conditions. 1 in 4 of us will be affected by heart related illness. Due to the global pandemic their research budget has been more than halved. Please help me support this amazing charity, so they can continue their life saving research.

story:
On the 27th of October 2020, our Mota (uncle), Dhiroobhai Mistry sadly passed away. 

Dhiroobhai was born in Nairobi, Kenya on 3rd December 1948. He came to the UK on 28th November 1970 with his mum (our grandma) and his younger brother, Dahyabhai (my dad) in search of a better future.

Mota was a third eldest out of four. Rameela ben (our moti foi) was the eldest, Manju ben (our nali foi), the second eldest, and my dad, Dahyabhai, the youngest. 

To those who have known Mota. He liked to talk, and he was also a devoted follower of Jalaram bapa.

When Mota came to the UK, he worked very hard to support his family. And like anyone who came to the UK from his generation, we can only thank them for making their sacrifices and for going through their struggles so that we, the current generation, can live a fulfilling life. We should never forget that. 

On the 21st December 1973, he married his wife, Dhanuben, and together they had two kids, Asmitaben and Prakashbhai. Sadly, Prakashbhai is no longer with us as he had passed away in May 2018.

The loss of our Mota follows the passing of our beloved moti foi, who also sadly died on 29th September this year. And my dad, who passed away over 8 years ago.

But I know, right now, Mota is with his younger brother, his eldest sister, his son and his own mum and dad. And I hope & pray that they've all found peace.

We have created this JustGiving page to raise money for the British Heart Foundation in memory of Dhiroobhai Mistry. The money that we help to raise can help to save life. 

Thank you, Jai Shree Krishna & Om Shanti

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

During October, we held a "Glitterbug - Iridescently Irresistible " festival styled shoot with a team of incredible suppliers to promote a popup glitter bar service.

Whilst we have put our own stamp on it, we were inspired by our good friend Hannah at Oh Snap UK. This initiative was something we had planned to do in partnership with Hannah. The challenges of 2020 meant that the partnership could sadly not happen - and it was with her blessing that we ran with the concept independently.

The Buttercup Bus team wanted to give credit to Hannah and Oh Snap UK for the idea, but wanted to do something more meaningful than just a name check. The hat and drum that feature in the shoot were made by Buttercup Bus, and we have decided to raffle these hand crafted, unique items (now with a little glitter on them from the shoot - ha ha!) in order to raise money for a charity that will resonate with both Hannah and the team at Buttercup Bus. 

Please buy a ticket for just £5, to help raise money for Cancer Research UK. Your ticket will be put in a glittery hat, and drawn at random on 30th November 2020. The lucky winner will get both the hat and the drum posted to them.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

(All entrants must have a UK delivery address. Draw takes place on 30th November 2020. You can buy as many tickets as you like, for multiple entries into the shoot. Each ticket is £5 to enter. Similar style hand  crafted hats range from £50-£150 on Etsy. The drum is so unique that we could not find an equivalent to value. They both feature in the header picture, taken by Tony Pullen Photography. Both items have been used once for the styled shoot, and will have eco-glitter flecks on them. They will be X-Mist sanitised before postage, in a Covid-safe way).

story:
2020 has impacted the lives of everyone, it has brought home just how much we really need support, and to support others in our community. This in mind, I feel we can all, as a community support each other, make a difference and finish this year on a positive vibe! 

Marie Curie provide care and support for around 2,500 people living with a terminal illness in Northern Ireland each year. They have been massively impacted by the pandemic and have not been able to carry out their vital fundraising activities including their Daffodil appeal. Yet the demands on their service keeps rising. 

To raise some funds for Marie Curie I am running a Christmas Raffle. The Raffle will take place on the 18th of December 2020.  Each ticket is £5.00 or you can buy 5 tickets for £20.00. Once you buy a ticket you are entered into the raffle to win one of the following prizes! 

Hamper containing Artisan Local Products from the Yellow Door, Long Meadow Cider, Scotch Street Shop Voucher, Knox's Meat Voucher, Christmas Wreath and more worth over £100.00 

Sarah Topley Artist Voucher for A4 Frame 

Sarah Topley Artist Voucher Cube Frame 

One 4 All Post Office Voucher £20.00

Tats and Tails Grooming Vouchers £40.00

Shauna McGrane Art Mounted Original Art Piece

Quote Frame by Hannah Pearson Art 

Little Beauty Room Voucher £25.00

Sally McNallys Meal Voucher £40.00 

Sally McNallys Meal Voucher £20.00 

Next Level Fitness Monthly Membership 

Rhiannon's Cakes and Bakes Christmas Cupcakes 

Tropic Gift Set  

All of the above prizes have been donated by these independent local businesses who themselves have faced challenging times this year, but are still prepared to put others first to help Marie Curie continue to give the much needed comfort that is totally invaluable to those with cancer, and their families. I thank you for supporting my raffle. I thank everyone for buying a ticket... every ticket counts! As every hour given by Marie Curie to a family makes a difference. Let's all make a difference and look forward to 2021! 

Thank you! 

Roisin x

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Over  the next five months I plan to swim 3 kms each month in unheated pools or the sea - arctic polar bear challenge, cycle at least 100 kms each month, rain and darkness notwithstanding and walk 80 kms each month (and not just around the house). And the final stretch is to walk the length of the Kennet and Avon Canal (not all at one go). The Covid lock down poses a challenge, and the darkness of winter is another issue, but they are there to be overcome. I shall post monthly updates, or even more frequently if something interesting happens. Marie Curie needs all the help they can get in this difficult time and I hope you will be able to support them.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
charity.registrationNumber: 288701 (England and Wales) and SC039479 (Scotland)
media.images.image.caption: NA
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. 

Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. 

It sounds normal and it should be.
